stem: The nurse is monitoring telemetry strips in the step-down unit. Match each rhythm with its characteristic ECG finding.

columns.text: Irregularly irregular rhythm with no discernible P-waves.
Rapid, regular rhythm (>150 bpm) with P-waves often hidden in T-waves.
P-waves and QRS complexes that are independent of each other (AV dissociation).

rationale.correct: ECG interpretation depends on P-to-QRS relationships. (r1) A-fib lacks organized atrial contraction (no P-waves). (r2) SVT is so fast the P-waves are 'buried'. (r3) In complete block, the atria and ventricles are 'divorced' and beat at different rates. (r4) First-degree block is just a delay in conduction (long PR).
rationale.incorrect: A-fib is irregular, whereas SVT and First-degree block are usually regular.
clinicalPearls: The primary risk of A-fib is clot formation in the atria, leading to an embolic stroke. Anticoagulation is mandatory.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: 0.20 is the magic number. If the PR is 0.22 and consistent, it's 1st degree. If it's variable and dropping, it's 2nd degree.

mnemonic.title: B-L-O-C-K
mnemonic.expansion: 1st (Consistent delay), 2nd-1 (Longer, longer, drop), 2nd-2 (Same PR, sudden drop), 3rd (Independent/Divorced).

reviewUnits.heading: Basic Dysrhythmia Interpretation
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must assess the patient first (Vitals/Symptoms) before treating the monitor. 3rd-degree block requires immediate external pacing if the patient is unstable.
